movie_review_blurb: It's USP is that it's "a red-necked Oceans" or "a hillbilly Oceans" so, in other words, it's a riff on Oceans. Soderbergh directed the Ocean's franchise, so it is hardly a stretch for him. Or us, for that matter.

With most films you know what you are getting within the first ten minutes -- oh, it's this film; OK -- but here there are no plot points as such and we never quite know where we're headed, which gives it the thrum of real life.
[Maudie] fulfils all our narrative expectations and you'll almost certainly exit the cinema happy, so long as you can leave it there.

This is essentially held together by the two lead performances. On paper, Bell has the lesser role, but this is his best performance to date... As for Bening, if she doesn't get Oscar-nominated this year, I will eat my hat, and also yours.
movie_title: Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It is small and specific, admittedly, but it also tells a universal story about a father's struggle to hold on to the son he loves, and it tells this story tenderly, thoughtfully, beautifully.
It is deeply unpleasant, if not deeply, deeply unpleasant. (Ideally, I would wish to repeat 'deeply' several hundred times, but I do not have the space.)
Based on the novella by Jonathan Ames, the film has the casual, sadistic violence of a Tarantino film, but none of the narrative inventiveness, as far as I could fathom. Or narrative clarity.
There are occasional fine, touching moments but, for the most part, it's as heavy-going as it is heavy-handed and some aspects are plain odd.

This is a coming-of-age story that's affecting without ever being sentimental, and feels absolutely true -- like remembering the teenager you once were, even if you were never a Lady Bird (or Debee) exactly. A rare bird indeed.
I liked it well enough, but not as much as I should have.
It is a bleak film, but Zvyagintsev's artistry means that it is not just compelling, but more involving than you'd ever think possible, given the two main characters are so unceasingly terrible.
Wilson? Enormously pleasurable company, since you ask. True, he's a lech, but such a gallant lech, plus he also gets irony.
It is a wonderfully fixating film in every respect, and wholly non-formulaic.

The trouble, basically, is that this film just doesn't know what it is about. Is it about dynasty? Imperialism? Ambition? The dark side of democracy? What? And, consequently, you are just not made to care about any of it.
Alas, LaBute loses it entirely in the third and final act, when he yields entirely to genre convention and allows it all to explode into a shoot-out of the utmost silliness.
This film is just such a wasted opportunity.

There are, alas, true weaknesses in this adaptation - too many close-ups of Colin Firth with tears in his eyes is one; too many mirror reflections are another - but it is neatly executed with a well-crafted script.
movie_title: When Did You Last See Your Father? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: So, in short? Well, the scenery is very pleasant and this film would kill a couple of hours on a plane. But I don't think I'd advise schlepping to the cinema rather than, say, staying at home for a nap then a bit of cheese.
It's actually the pile up of clichés and implausibilities that make the whole thing such a slog.
True enough, it's make-believe, but to believe in make-believe, you do have to be firmly on board in some way. Otherwise, it's just nonsense.
Unrelated observes the English upper-middle classes so astutely that, at times, it is almost painful to watch.
The bulk of this movie, alas, comes down to weak sketches held together by ridiculous action, vast explosions and more or less everything else it should be parodying.
Stunning to look at, but as an engaging, illuminating, convincing piece of cinema? No, not really.
It offers a jumble of barely explored, quarter-baked ideas attached to a laborious plot.
It's a bit of a Trojan horse, as it cleverly smuggles in another film; a film about a woman coming into her own, which has to be satisfying. And is.
The narrative never goes where you think it will go. Instead, it takes your narrative expectations and shreds them before your eyes.
I'll tell you what Brad's status should be: face well and truly slapped.
There's no nuance, no reflective downtime, and it ends with what may be the worst cod-psychology scene of all time. It all comes down to daddy issues, apparently. Oh, boo-hoo.
The film is not unsuccessful, as it's mostly entertaining enough, and if the gender politics seem oversimplified, there are reminders of some real-life commentaries.
The Big Sick is a rom-com that's smarter than most rom-coms, which isn't saying much, admittedly.
It's a proper story alright, and a fascinating one.
This is clever, tense, gripping, told at a lick -- it's less than 90 minutes -- and while revenge is a dish best served cold, it's pretty good served this way too.
Even though it does require you to spend nearly three hours in a min-van with young people who turn up the music real loud, you will not, in fact, regret it.
There is no psychological dimension as the characters aren't characters as such, more cogs in the plot machine.
McConaughey brings more gravitas and intensity to the role than the role probably deserves. But what he can't bring is complexity, as there is none.
As directed by Colm McCarthy, it is dully and ploddingly told, without imagination, suspense, tension, or any sense of mounting dread.
movie_title: The Girl With All the Gifts (2017)

movie_review_blurb: I would say I probably don't care enough to see this at the cinema, but if I happened upon it on TV I would happily stay for the duration, and that's the sort of film it is.
It's a repetitive rehash rather than a worthwhile continuation of the character, and the comedy and pathos is in exactly the same place as it always was.
movie_title: David Brent: Life on the Road (2017)

movie_review_blurb: There's every chance you'll hate it. I'm not convinced I don't. But this is a film that, once seen, you'll always know you've seen and, in the most disquieting way, it feels as if it has somehow seen you too.
The performances are possibly fine. König is suitably endearing while Cox rages vigorously against the dying of the light, but as everything else is so hackneyed, it all seems rather pointless.
To describe this story as multilayered doesn't do it justice.
It's OK. It's not a disaster. And it doesn't vindicate the naysayers. This film fails to fly not because it stars women, but because that's the only good idea it had.
You will often have to watch through your fingers, so cringe inducing are some of the scenes.

Perhaps you have sometimes wondered: how would you even begin to make a film about going blind and being blind and what that means?... Even if that's so you'll still find Notes on Blindness to be a singular achievement, as well as a truly wonderful one.

What we have here, in effect, is a generic action movie in which the main players happen to be animals, but could just as well be people. Still, the six-year-old 'loved it' which would count for something, if only it did.
This is fantastically unhinged, veering madly between wonder and horror, gorgeousness and grotesquery.
movie_title: Tale of Tales (Il racconto dei racconti) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Every now and then, with great infrequency (alas), a film comes along that is like no other and completely knocks you for six, and that is Embrace of the Serpent.
movie_title: Embrace Of The Serpent (El Abrazo De La Serpiente) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: You won't care it's been done before, because it's never been done like this.

Even though this is a walking and talking film, except in those instances when it's a sitting and talking film, Stillman keeps everything moving fast, fast, fast while the script crackles and spits and bites.
I found it a bit weird, I grant you, but also wise and thought-provoking -- and strangely hypnotic.
I was fed up of them all by the end, I have to say.
It is ultimately unsatisfying, as a psychological profile and otherwise.
Look, I don't begrudge those who love the Avengers, as they so passionately do. I'm just genuinely perplexed.
Jane Got a Gun is being sold as a rousing feminist Western although the truth is that it's about as rousing and feminist as my cat, Daphne, who is 17, and now barely moves.
It is brave, and even admirable, but if you are fond of an emotional core? Then you will sorely feel the lack of it.
I won't describe the aliens in detail here because the reveal is 87.4 per cent of the fun. I will say only that they're monstrous but also strangely balletic and tender.

Indignation is an adaptation of Philip Roth's 2008 novel and amazingly, for an adaptation of a Philip Roth novel -- see the recent dog's dinner that was American Pastoral, for example -- it may even be worth two hours of your time.
Fearsomely moving (I cried), and fearsomely tender (I cried again).
It's psychologically thin, tiresomely hagiographic and doesn't answer any of the questions you'd like it to answer.
The performances are all strong, but how anyone can say this doesn't bolt headlong into all the usual horror clichés, I don't know.
The car-chase movie reinvented? Maybe, but it just hasn't been reinvented enough.
Gleeson is a fine actor in most circumstances, but here the material is so thin he's given nothing to work with, or against, as there are no decent jokes, and there's almost no drama.
It is highly watchable, and remember: what God takes away with one hand he gives with the other. No, it isn't sufficiently dark, twisted or tense, but the bonnets and the wisteria are lovely. Truly.
The fact is, Pirates, you are so insultingly lazy it's a wonder anyone puts up with you at all. If you were a person, I'd have thrown you out the house years ago.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: There is no character development at all. Obviously, one wasn't expecting Terms of Endearment, but the two leads are so thinly sketched it prevents any moments of genuine emotion, and gives us no reason to like them.
This circumvents all our expectations, plays like a thriller, ditches bonnets for more murderous pursuits, and is plain terrific.

Rules is entirely baffling. Is it a tale of Old Hollywood? Is it a biopic of Howard Hughes? Is it a love story? Unfortunately, it can never decide, so tries to be all of the above and therefore succeeds at none.
The performances are transfixing throughout. But it does not satisfy emotionally, as the ending of The Sense of an Ending makes no sense. It's a (Non)Sense of an Ending.

It's serviceable. It won't be the biggest disappointment in your life. The story's too good for it to get away completely. But it's simplistic, exposition-heavy, joyless and focuses on the obstacles to their love rather than the love itself.

The world is populated by blandly one-dimensional characters. Evil is perpetrated by our old friend, Corporate Evil Man -- yes, still -- and everyone communicates via dialogue so stilted and ham-fisted it makes you die inside a little.
You will, I promise, be profoundly moved.
As a general rule poetry does not make good cinema, but this one succeeds more than most.

This film is beautiful to look at, but if it has anything to say about sex, violence, desire, it all passed me by. Rape should be shown on screen, if only to challenge it, but if this does any of that challenging, that too passed me by.
This has its visually wondrous moments, and the lead (Lewis MacDougall) is a true find, but there's too much bark, too little bite.
It's the kind of story that has been told countless times, and here it's told in such a perfunctory, plodding way that it brings nothing new to the party.
La La Land with caveats is still more wonderful than almost anything else.
Was I riveted by Natalie Portman as Jackie Kennedy? I was... But was I aware it was Natalie Portman, Acting? Always. And there isn't much else here.
Silence is Martin Scorsese's film about Jesuit priests in 17th-century Japan whose faith is sorely tested, just as your patience will be sorely tested too.

It has its highly entertaining moments, and there is some fun to be had in McConaughey's madly over-zealous performance but it is derivative and there are so many storytelling impulses on the go that none has any hope of ever hitting home.
While all the cast are sublime, this is Bening's film. She is incredible. It is a performance of the utmost nuance.
This is a deeply compassionate film that not only does astounding work on the being black, being gay front, but is also about anybody who feels they exist outside the world they've been born into.
I've decided it probably is a failure, but that you haven't heard the last from Dolan.
movie_title: It's Only the End of the World (Juste la fin du monde) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: On to the characters, who were sad and despairing back in the day, but always empathetic and never victims. Here... well, I'm not that sure who they are.
Most patient adults may want to strangle the impish Elmo within the first 10 minutes of this movie.
movie_title: The Adventures of Elmo in Grouchland (1999)

movie_review_blurb: What doesn't work is how it is so eager to frighten without a protagonist to root for.
It sails smoothly from start to finish and feels like a pleasant adventure, even if it is not particularly memorable.
The film does not feel like it gives sufficient exploration of the temptation of Christ, but there is no denying the deep spirituality and thought-provoking nature of it.
Unfortunately, the lack of development in the plot and characters make this romantic escape feel less than satisfying in the end.
Unfortunately, The Rezort is a film that wants to be taken seriously, but is so lacking in originality that it simply falls apart.
Director James Wan, a veteran of the horror genre, has no problems torturing his viewers with tension before unleashing hell.
The theme of human enslavement to technology is still there, but Cell does not dive any further - besides the occasional reminder about the prevalence of telecommunication devices.
The movie is interesting but that is not nearly enough to entertain, even if only for 106 minutes.
movie_title: April and the Extraordinary World (Avril et le monde truqué) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The jokes and story do not hold a candle to their predecessor, but there are enough funny and moving moments to make this a pretty solid family flick.
What saves the entire thing is Skarsgard, who steals the spotlight by striking the balance between a ruthless figure and a loving family man.
Even though fans will probably enjoy the rare glimpse of reclusive Prince frolicking on the big screen, better to buy the album (as well as Pandemonium by The Time) than to waste money on this dreck.

It is one of the few films so visually absorbing, felicitous shot after shot, that its emotional coldness is noticed only at the end, when all the plot twists are unraveled in a solid piece of thinking-man's entertainment for upmarket thriller audiences.

Huge immediacy and topicality are not inconsiderable virtues in a documentary attempting to tell the world some true things about the Arab spring as it played out in Egypt, ending in the arrest and trial of president Hosni Mubarak.
movie_title: In Tahrir Square: 18 Days Of Egypt's Unfinished Revolution (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A youthful, melancholy film that draws on literature and writing for its inspiration.
A hard-boiled Spanish police thriller about a good cop gone bad hits the genre spot.
Wim Wenders' stylish 3D mirrors the bizarrely captivating world of choreographer Pina Bausch.
Conveys a sense of the writer's personal life and his independent thinking, never banal and rarely disconnected from the world around him.
Tensely involving Iranian drama with niche potential.
A long, slow haul but for the willing, a haunting journey into the heart of darkness in Turkish Anatolia.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in Anatolia (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The film's pace races through events in a chain of escalating violence, tension, smoke and gunfire.
The promise of the whimsical title "Police, Adjective" is fulfilled at the end of this likable, cinematically sophisticated but slow-moving police procedural.
Historical drama set in the early days of the French revolution is intelligent Euro eye candy at its most lavish.
Modern love shifts from Hong Kong to Beijing in the successful sequel to Love in a Puff, a natural, light and convincing rom com very similar to the original Hong Kong hit.
Richard Coyle and a strong supporting cast lend interest to a London-set remake of Nicolas Winding Refn's 1996 Danish gangster thriller.
Live-action follow-up to "Persepolis" set in 1950s Iran blends humor and poetry with delightful artistry.
A disappointingly obvious follow-up to [Garrone's] unsparing criminal drama Gomorra...
Resonating with layers of personal and political meaning, the messy aftermath of the Egyptian revolution is captured with immediacy and excitement.
This is less a film about terrorists than an intimate portrait of boys growing up in a toxic environment.
Promises a lot but lacks conviction, feeling like a case study with a very arbitrary ending.
Confused, at times naive story-telling eventually gives way to a powerful dramatic finale, but one so downbeat it leaves a bitter taste in the mouth...
Ambitious and entertaining fantasy examines multiple lives and choices.
Classy and professional throughout, the technical work gracefully holds all the threads together.
"Scheherazade, Tell Me a Story" is a powerful indictment of misogyny that overturns stereotypes about Egypt through the dramatic stories women recount on a television show.
Surprisingly few surprises in this classic samurai costumer from Japan's dark iconoclast Takeshi Miike.
Michael Nyman's sweepingly majestic score lends an epic dimension, which feels right alongside the straight-forward passion depicted by an evenly balanced, top-drawer cast.
Constructed like an eerie, metaphorical thriller, this tense, riveting character study offers viewers nearly two hours of emotions with a stunning pay-off no one will be expecting.
A superb work of Japanese fantasy from animation wizard Miyazaki that transcends age barriers.

Director John Hillcoat has performed an admirable job of bringing Cormac McCarthy's Pulitzer Prize-winning novel to the screen as an intact and haunting tale, even at the cost of sacrificing color, big scenes and standard Hollywood imagery.
This is a typical Moore oeuvre: funny, often over the top and of dubious documentation, but with strongly made points that leave viewers much to ponder and debate after they walk out of the theater.
With material like this, one would have liked a more incisive comedy to materialize around the decline and fall of the New Age movement.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: An exciting thriller from Argentina capable of crossing borders.
movie_title: The Secret in Their Eyes (El Secreto de Sus Ojos) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Dazzling nature doc chooses poetry and wonder over storytelling and effects.
A heady mix of deadpan humor that boldly uses such topics as pedophilia, race and terrorism to plead the need for forgiveness at a personal and national level.
Breathtaking sets and effects give this youthful martial arts film a modern air.
movie_title: Detective Dee and the Mystery of the Phantom Flame (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Seven years after Divine Intervention, director Elia Suleiman returns with more humorous-sad stories from his native Palestine, couched in the ironic autobiographical language at which he is grandly adept.
A political film with a message of hope, on the obvious side.
Despite its subject, Coppola seems to be exercising more of her European than American sensibility in the small-scale intimacy of this portrait.
Joaquin Phoenix and Casey Affleck push the edges of celebrity spoof in a mockumentary worth watching.
A realistic slice of pioneer life that offers a disquieting alternative vision of America's most mythic location.
Both spectacular and pious, "Tsar" positions itself between Sergei Eisenstein's "Ivan the Terrible" and Andrei Tarkovsky's "Andrei Rublev," though without their originality and inspiration.
Far less daring than her 1999 Titus, which took an electrifying, stylized approach of a lesser-known play, The Tempest in comparison looks disappointingly middle-of-the-road.
A superbly guilty pleasure for a rainy day.
After years of working on photography, poetry and more experimental films, Abbas Kiarostami makes an engaging return to narrative cinema in a delicate, bittersweet comedy set in romantic Italy.
Potiche has plenty of contemporary sparkle and life, courtesy of a masterful central performance by grande dame Catherine Deneuve as an oppressed bourgeois housewife who finds liberation.
[A] long, elegantly shot, sporadically involving Japanese film.
A dizzying explosion of an Indian gangster film, whose epic structure and colorful, immoral killers capture the imagination for over five hours.
Enjoyable enough, this colorfully local, nostalgia-tinged tale focuses on the Hong Kong years of an older, gentlemanly kung fu master.
Ward ... flounders around for an effective tone between comedy and drama in his first solo effort.
Stephen Frears returns to top form in a touching, at times funny true story of grave injustice and a mother's search for closure.
A sometimes fascinating, sometimes not, four-hour visit to the Berkeley campus offers insights into what the great, sprawling public university is today.
Though it's packed with adorable tykes and more than a few strong scenes, even Kore-eda fans may feel a let-down with a lovely film that makes little emotional connection

As hauntingly strange as it is inconclusive and frustrating, Enemy, directed by Denis Villeneuve (Incendies), is one of the more head-scratching additions to the doppelganger genre. Yet it will certainly have its fans.

A serious European financial thriller is something of a novelty, and Costa-Gavras, the militant film master par excellence, shows perfect timing in his ambitious Capital, a film that lingers in the memory in spite of being rather irritating to watch.
This big-budget English-language co-production shows that Europeans can compete in the sci-fi realm where high production values are king.

Zeiler, a relatively unknown actor outside of German TV, energetically fills the main role with quick intelligence and unflagging self-confidence, which helps the viewer negotiate the dangerous ground he walks on.
Sensitive lensing and acting render an unusual story of brotherly love touching in a promising first film.
Sure-footed scripting and a stand-out performance by Luminita Gheorghiu freshen a potentially pat subject.
Irresistible trashy fun in a cross-genre free-for-all.
movie_title: Why Don't You Play in Hell? (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Dustin Hoffman's directing debut about retired musicians in the third act of their lives has a winning, classy charm for older audiences.
Serious story-telling is about the only thing that unites these short stories.
A powerful reflection on the beginning of Hitler's Final Solution is seen through the intelligent, sardonic eyes of an aged eyewitness.
Its astute use of a modern deep-focus, 3D idiom creates the engrossing immediacy of a large-scale disaster film.
A cagey mixture of action and horror, with a standout performance from Daniel Wu.
The sinister interest a Nazi physician takes in a 12-year-old girl and her family makes for a chilling, original tale.

If it wasn't for the charming top-liners who can make literary dialogue sound sexy in their sleep, the war in Fred Schepisi's Words and Pictures would have to be called off after the opening skirmish.

With typical intelligence and complexity, director Marco Bellocchio weaves three stories around the politically hot topic of euthanasia, turning a real-life Italian national drama into engrossing narrative for sophisticated audiences.
This bold piece of docu-fiction, an open protest against censorship and the repression of individual liberties, will no doubt make waves in Iran.
movie_title: No One Knows About Persian Cats (Les Chats Persans) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: An excellent ensemble cast, led by Liam Neeson, Adrien Brody, Mila Kunis and James Franco doesn't disappoint, though they struggle to keep things afloat over a running time of more than two hours.

Geoffrey Rush brings striking depth of character to a classic Old World mystery set against the sophisticated backdrop of Europe's art auctions, with charming input from Jim Sturgess and Donald Sutherland.
Rosales continues his exploration of the way unexpected acts of violence brutally alter the course of human lives.
The first feature ever shot in Saudi Arabia is a winner directed by a woman, Haifaa Al Mansour.
Something of a roller coaster and fairly bumpy, the ride is the problem here.
Dan Algrant's lyrical recreation of a father-son relationship seen over time, through memory and music, has a sense of urgent originality that works even apart from its great Tim Buckley score.
Fantastic visuals and non-stop action make for a spectacular, romantic Chinese CGI feast.
movie_title: Bai she chuan shuo (The Sorcerer and the White Snake) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A tremendously realistic disaster movie has an intense emotional payoff.
There is surprisingly little emotional resonance with the well-drawn and acted characters, making it a tiring two and a half hour trek for filmgoers who don't have a stake in the history it recounts.
Consummate acting helps ease a painful watch, as Michael Haneke describes the ultimate test of love in a profoundly honest study of sickness and dying.
The fresh and simple story will win its share of young fans, though it lacks the disturbing adult elements might have attracted older audiences.
Strained attempt at WWII tragi-comedy isn't funny.
The sensitively imagined story of a child soldier in Africa makes War Witch a genre benchmark and a breakout work for writer-director Kim Nguyen.

With such an in-house cast of extended Coppola family sparklers, one would think things couldn't go too wrong in the comedy department, but they have little chance to oil the wheels of a creaky script written around Sheen.
movie_title: A Glimpse Inside the Mind of Charles Swan III (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A film about the beauty of flight and the prelude to war, whose astonishing visuals shout that life is wonderful.
The tense dialogue between East and Post post-9/11 is turned into a tense, often gripping duet between a young Muslim professor and American reporter.

There is just about enough narrative to hold interest, while the lyrical camerawork, constantly in motion, blurred images and all, offers a single emotion that is impossible to stretch over a feature-length film.
A grungy, dark police procedural set in motion by a little girl's kidnapping, Ugly has few discernible auteur touches to set it apart from standard genre fare.
They are of varying interest, but the overall impression they leave is watching a Bollywood sampler without the song and dance, a committee project with an impressive budget but little heart.
Referencing without imitating Fellini, Sorrentino offers an amusing update on Italian society at the end of a cycle.
A strong storyline about the West Bank and its endless cycle of violence leaves interpretation up to the viewer.
Images and metaphors whimsicially combine in a fine, fast-flowing documentary introducing the Baha'i faith.
Dynamic chase film hits all the right buttons to fascinate edge-of-seat cop op addicts.
Inert Canadian-French drama attempts to explore the motivation behind a suicide bombing.
A humorous, humanistic approach enlivens an inventive documentary feature about people living around Rome's ring road
Finely wrought and acted psychological drama cleverly plays on the repressed violence and projections of a Turkish family on holiday.
Director Ron Howard and his crew have worked hard to make Professor Robert Langdon's return a thrilling, faster-paced walk in the park.
A large cast of youthful performers, including the director and scriptwriters, at first seem awkwardly lifted from the stage, but begin to emerge as believable characters by and by.
This simple, repetetive tale has a mesmerizing quality able to hook audiences from beginning to end.
movie_title: The Story of Qiu Ju (Qiu Ju da guan si) (1992)

movie_review_blurb: British documakers Kim and Florence Ayisi present a surprisingly positive portrait of the justice system in a small town in Cameroon.
Meshkini communicates a personal vision in terms all women (and certainly many men) can feel deeply.
movie_title: Roozi ke zan shodam (The Day I Became a Woman) (2001)

movie_review_blurb: The dialogue has a pleasing low-key realism that complements Soderbergh's understated direction, though one can sense a firm hand always guiding the straightforward story.
A powerful portrait of the Spanish spirit, particularly the gypsy culture of Andalusia.
Shows little interest in making sense.
Marcelo Gomes makes an impressive if sober feature helming debut in Cinema, Aspirin and Vultures.
movie_title: Cinema, Asprin And Vultures (cinema, Aspirinas E Urubus) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: In its quiet way, Taraneh touches the hot issues -- jail, divorce, teenage love, unwed maternity -- and comes up with a convincing, positive answer to all.
Though the storyline is dirt simple (can friendship outlive jealousy?) and not particularly meaningful or involving, the action in this character-driven film is scintillatingly sexy.

A contrived, rather unpleasant English-lingo thriller set in the Netherlands and Luxembourg, Moonlight takes a precocious love story between a young rich girl and an Afghan boy to kinky limits where few auds will want to tread.

A study in courage and harrowing portrait of a 14-year-old boy who works in a Bolivian silver mine, The Devil's Miner is an unforgettable journey through hell under the earth, where Satan is worshipped as king.

The lifelong shame and trauma experienced by the victims of childhood incest are grippingly dramatized by Cristina Comencini, consummate mistress of Italian family drama, in Don't Tell, probably her most successful film.
Its undeniable appeal lies in shocking frankness shackled to irony, a combo that should attract indie lovers with psychoanalytic leanings and droll senses of humor.
Powerfully co-directed by Michael Winterbottom and Mat Whitecross, the film has a winning combo of excitement and topicality.
Besides the fine Bakovic, the cast does a splendid job fleshing out unconventional roles.
The pic's torturously slow pace turns an earnest effort into a tedious aesthetic exercise.
The Yacoubian Building distinguishes itself both as the most expensive Egyptian film ever made and, despite its nearly three-hour running time, one of the most watchable.
Though weak in the drama department, the story of a brother and sister who love each other but have different political ideas and personal agendas effectively captures the tension of the time.
A frustratingly slow drama.
Promises much more than it delivers.
Radiates a warm humanity and uplifts the spirit.
Comedy veteran Paolo Virzi brings a light helming touch to a story with a lot to say about contemporary Italy.
Though the comedy's not all that sparkling and the cast generally uninspired, pic is pretty to look at.
This enjoyable French pic welds together drama, melodrama and comedy in a blend with potentially strong European audience appeal.
An easy intro to new Lebanese cinema... chronicling the country's post-civil war emptiness with a light touch as it zaps between playful clowning and edge-of-violence darkness.
Bringing a fiery warmth and accessibility to the central role, [Hayek] proves a good match for the artist as she depicts Kahlo's indomitable will to live, love and paint.
Sharif sparkles as a Turkish grocery store owner and self-styled philosopher who brings sunshine into the life of a lonely boy.
movie_title: Monsieur Ibrahim et les fleurs du Coran (Monsieur Ibrahim) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Timely and thought-provoking, if a bit rambling.
movie_title: Forget Baghdad: Jews and Arabs - The Iraqi Connection (2003)

movie_review_blurb: It moves forward on the sheer strength of its portraiture, thanks to an exceptionally good ensemble cast that brings the inmates to life as individuals, not genre types.
Most successful are the mini-comedies with a loose punchline, while others barely qualify as character sketches.
The two things that keep the film from falling into laughable melodrama are its continual inventions on a stylistic level ... and the exceptional level of acting.
One has the feeling the director has let himself go off the deep end regarding the romantic and idealizing tendencies that, for better or worse, characterize much of his work.
Though the film's multiple strands strain to blend, they do give the protags' ill-fated romance a level of deeper, more involving meaning.

Somewhere between Monty Python, Jacques Tati and a slideshow of New Yorker cartoons, this critique of life's cruel inconsistency confirms the French co-directors' gift for reinterpreting surrealism in a humorously modern key.

Takes the viewer on a mysterious and sporadically fascinating trip into the darkness of the human heart and Thai legend, but only after an hour of a weakly structured story about two young men who are attracted to each other.
The film has humanity to burn, but its loose structure makes it hard to connect with the multiple characters.
A film destined to divide Manoel de Oliveira's fans but also to win him new ones.
Twin Sisters has the engrossing quality of a big historical novel and about the same level of sentimental artistry.

The sensitive dual female role for femme lead Radha Mitchell stirs memories of complex Allen heroines from Annie Hall on down, even if the action is dispersed via a larger ensemble cast which he currently favors.
A kinky Brazilian offering packed with good ideas in a sophisticated horror vein, but disappointing in the unraveling.
The connections [Kiarostami] makes between his cinema and Italian neo-realism will interest scholars, students and fledgling directors.
A fascinating if somewhat morbid study.
Both intensely exciting for its cinematic inventions and terribly uninvolving on emotional and dramatic levels.
The tight pacing of Michael Hudecek and Nadine Muse's editing keeps the story fluid and focused but very concise, commanding audience attention from start to finish.
Upscale auds will enjoy the film's affectionate portrait of the diva, coupled with a selection of her great recordings and Zeffirelli's dazzling, fictional stagings of Carmen.
An engaging if uneven tale that outstays its welcome, Sonhos de peixe describes the life and loves of a teenage lobster diver from a poor Brazilian fishing village.
A somber, beautifully acted reflection on the barbarity of war and the bestiality of man, which only enormous compassion can redeem.
The buoyant little comedy 12:08 East of Bucharest puts its finger on the problem in the best tradition of East European humor, savvy but concrete, gentle but sharp as a knife.
movie_title: 12:08 East of Bucharest (A fost sau n-a fost?) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Apart from a few tour de force dance scenes, though, the rhythm tends to drag.
One of those rare docs capable of holding its own in an official selection of fiction films.

Following her more on-target I Like to Work (Mobbing) about workplace harassment, and her delicate Italo Svevo adaptation My Father's Words, this film comes as something of a let-down from the wide-ranging director.
Though it sounds like an offbeat idea even for horror fans, the tech work is so well done that it could disarm unwary buffs attracted by the campy title.
movie_title: Dracula: Pages From a Virgin's Diary (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Sensitive, delicate and involving...
movie_title: The Year My Parents Went on Vacation (O Ano em Que Meus Pais Saíram de Férias) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Documaker Chico Teixeira gives a light, natural feel to his small but fetching first feature, set in a working class household in Sao Paulo that gets turned upside down by everyday dramas of sexual and emotional betrayal.
Unreal characters and story shackle this gloomy tale of unconventional love between a long-lost brother and sister.
Splashy, noisy and downright fun.
A tense documentary with multiple layers of meaning.
A fairly successful attempt at satire, though given the subject, there's a lot of darkness under the carpet.
[A] beautifully crafted and lively romp around the 1880s stage world.
A film whose lightness of touch rides a wave of family conflict to perfectly balance smiles and tears.

Tensely action-packed and muscularly directed by Kathryn Bigelow, this tale of an elite U.S. army bomb disposal unit in Baghdad is a familiar story in new clothes, targeted at the young male demographic.
Before the Rain is a visually and narratively stunning tale in three parts, set between modern London and the timeless hills of Macedonia, in former Yugoslavia
A morbidly fascinating prep school tragedy which also is a stylistically uncompromisingly vision of hypocritical America.
Powerful, emotional filmmaking and acting give a lift to the familiar women-in-prison film.
The story, spiked with gentle humor, moves smoothly through the standard tropes of Iranian art house cinema.
A surprisingly deep tale about a middle-aged German couple discovering love on the brink of death.
The film has major problems blending the strong social theme of exploitation and white slavery with Tornatore's noirish screenplay, full of holes and improbabilities.
Emir Kusturica's epic black comedy about Yugoslavia from 1941 to 1992 is a three-hour steamroller circus that leaves the viewer dazed and exhausted, but mightily impressed.
Stumbles into a lame love story and ends in a conventional shootout and bloodbath.
An irresistible treat for connoisseurs and the uninitiated alike, pic will be a bracing surprise for anyone who has forgotten how exciting music, dance and voice can be.
The pic should suck even landlubbers into a whirlpool of gripping adventure, overblown ambitions and sheer human folly.
A film that touches the heartstrings as it brings home the cruel class distinctions that poison Indian society.
Ambitiously trying to blend the joys of growing up with the melancholy of living in a country under one of the worst dictatorships in Eastern Europe, this warm story does have a tendency to ramble.
movie_title: The Way I Spent the End of the World (Cum mi-am petrecut sfarsitul lumii) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Killing makes a man a man in the puzzling To Get to Heaven You Have to Die, an artfully lensed but psychologically unpersuasive initiation tale from Tajikistan.
movie_title: To Get to Heaven, First You Have to Die (Bihisht faqat baroi murdagon) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Rather miraculously, pic succeeds in painlessly educating its viewers about global politics and economics while it describes contemporary Africa with freshness and clarity.

Though functional on its own terms, this fourth feature by Israel Adrian Caetano feels hollow at the core, leaving a feeling of lingering disappointment over a missed opportunity to probe recent history.
A tiresomely silly film that suffers from overacting and an overwritten script.
At a two-hour-plus running time, only the most stout-hearted fans of cold-blooded art cinema will stick around to find out how much misery awaits the unwary and not too bright heroine.
When the master of French thrillers Claude Chabrol meets the mistress of English suspense fiction Ruth Rendell, the result is a potent if very classic blend.
A galloping fable full of offbeat characters and entertaining moments.
Much of the pic's strength is in leaning on the frail shoulders of newcomer Dorotheea Petre, who is insightful and refreshingly contemporary as a boy-girl-woman searching for her identity.
A fast-moving, engrossing multiple-character drama that brings the AIDS crisis of the 1980s into laser focus.
A passionate outcry for peace and justice in America that becomes deeply involving by the final climactic scene, overlaid with one of RFK's most stirring speeches.
Almost a sinful pleasure is Andrey Zhegalov's striking widescreen cinematography.

Using a simple storytelling style that grows stronger with each passing scene, Dry Season draws the viewer into its small two-character drama set in post-war Chad, while it offers a deep reflection on injustice and frustrated revenge.
Sophisticated auds will enjoy this thoroughly modern spoof on masculine fixations, played out in frank, realistic dialogue.
The even-handed film is sympathetic to the Cuban revolution in its initial stages, then slowly swings around to reveal the 'skeleton of a dream' that the society has become.
movie_title: The Sugar Curtain (El Telon de azucar) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A surprisingly layered vehicle for a maniacally conniving Richard Gere, backed up by a superb Alfred Molina as his accomplice.
Audiences hooked on Persian mainstream will devour this irreverent romantic comedy, spiced with saucy dialogue that spoofs traditional gender roles through gritted teeth.
Containing a bare minimum of suspense and excitement, story unspools like a shaggy dog story missing the punchline.

Contagiously upbeat The Orchestra of Piazza Vittorio is a rousing call to arms for world-music aficionados, with strong appeal to those who believe in the mini-miracles of neighborhood cultural initiatives.
The idea of linking the vampire myth to the city's depressing sociopolitical climate is more intriguing than film itself.
Oliveira's short but sweet rumination on growing old and the fading of sexual desire is not only high-concept, but one of his most watchable.
A complex film-within-a-film structure uses the favorite techniques of reflexive Iranian cinema to assert the need to recount reality.
Though the story is fictional, the imagery is grounded in a powerful documentary reality.
movie_title: In the Last Days of the City (Akher ayam el madina) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Though it abounds in the kind of sardonic humor intrinsic to life's absurdities, the film is rarely laugh-out-loud funny. In a nutshell, quiet desperation prevails.
movie_title: A Pigeon Sat on a Branch Reflecting on Existence (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Both Redford and Fonda are charming, delicate and convincing as Addie Moore and Louis Waters, the couple who find each other at the tail end of their lives. They are directed with sophistication and without a drop of melodrama or sentimentality ...
Each character resonates as a problematic individual whose foolishness escalates first into drama, then tragedy.
Bold modernist cinema at its most harrowing.
A road movie short on comedy and drama should at least offer a keen level of observation, but here insight is scarce and emotional resonance is faint.
Lensed with great sensitivity and style and superbly acted, it has one drawback for Western audiences in its perplexing plot points based on the local culture and customs.
Never talking down to his audience, [Wiseman] rather pulls them up to an intellectual level where other filmmakers fear to go.
movie_title: Ex Libris: New York Public Library (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A complex and engrossing examination of truth.
Like flipping through the pages of a pulpy best-seller, watching Loving Pablo has its moments of guilty pleasure but leaves an empty feeling when you reach the end.
Holds the viewer in its genteel grip from start to almost finish.
The sophisticated tech work feels a bit sad and empty ... reflecting the spirit of the story.
Solid, straightforward and touching.
Its non-stop feminist message can get a little heavy-handed at times, but the story pushes all the right buttons for women viewers and hopefully for a good number of little boys, too.
Once Pacino is surrounded by other characters, the comedy comes thick and fast and the material begins to come together in an absurd sort of way.
Consistently describes an ambitious talent always reaching for the top, but also a man plagued by insecurity, who remained sadly unsure of his own value.
movie_title: Sammy Davis, Jr.: I've Gotta Be Me (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A fascinating glimpse into New Zealand's contemporary Maori community, Waru brings a sense of dramatic, urgent realism to a story that plays out like a suspenseful mystery.
It's the kind of cartoonish film where, no matter what the odds and how many bullets are flying at our heroes, they never get seriously injured. Everyone else dies.
At once a summing-up of the Tavianis' filmmaking and an affirmation of their unshaken belief that human life is an uneasy compromise between the private and political spheres.
movie_title: Rainbow: A Private Affair (Una questione privata) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Though the basic plot about a despised underdog who, against overwhelming odds, grits his teeth and trains for the big match could hardly be less clichéd, its cinematic level of invention makes sure that much more is going on.
A bloody one-note horror film.
[A] long, engrossing, visually stunning documentary ...

Nicchiarelli dives deeply into the life of a tragic but remarkable woman, memorably portrayed by Danish actress and singer Trine Dyrholm as an unpleasant, hurtful junkie plagued with memories and regrets.
Lipstick is audaciously outspoken about women's sexual desires and fantasies, both visually and verbally.
Not an easy watch but a highly rewarding one.
At once historically impeccable and a filmic disappointment.
movie_title: The Young Karl Marx (Le jeune Karl Marx) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Gripping from start to finish.
A relentless stylishness unifies the film, extending from the hard bright lights of upscale Taipei all the way to the sleaziest junkyard of rural Japan, where the action unfolds.
A plotless but wryly likeable study of human emotions.
movie_title: On the Beach at Night Alone (Bamui haebyun-eoseo honja) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Beautiful to look at and strangely haunting.

The gears in The Salesman are not so hidden and a sense of contrived drama leads to some tedious sections. But all is forgiven when the final punches are delivered in a knock-out finale that leaves the viewer tense and breathless.
[An] involving, fable-like drama.
Some close observations redeem an uninspired tale of urban alienation.
movie_title: Tokyo Night Sky Is Always the Densest Shade of Blue (Yozora wa itsudemo saikô mitsudo no aoiro da) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Shot with undeniable intensity but rather less technique, the film has an uneasy lack of structure as it circles around topics and returns to themes over and over.
It fascinatingly blurs the line between fantasy and reality, from the eerie intro all the way through to a surprise finale that raises goosebumps.

If Grassadonia and Piazza had simply retold the story, it would have been gripping enough, but they deepen the intensity and widen the meaning by letting the tale unfold in a strange filmic space between cruel reality and ghostly fantasy.
An audacious, if somewhat didactic, debut.
A short and sweet divertissement with a few profound punchlines.
There seems to be something missing here.
A high-adrenaline tale of fighting, shooting, stabbing and killing interrupted by quiet stretches of backstory and character development.
The ravishing "natural" beauty of the scenes has been masterfully contrived by the camera lens, aperture and framing.
It has its harrowing moments, but the psychological thriller Jasmine is an impenetrable mystery for most of its running time, and deliberately so.
A thriller made riveting by an emotional performance from Diane Kruger.
A masterfully made psychological thriller in the traditional mode.
movie_title: Based on a True Story (D'après une histoire vraie) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Its visual style and pacing make as much of an impression as the head-shaking story.
An uncompromising drama from one of Iran's most outspoken directors.
The ending is left deliberately, unsatisfyingly ambiguous, but whatever her fate may be, in or out of the system, it doesn't matter that much to the viewer.
Pass the steak sauce, please.
Gabizon daringly explores this premise as an ironic, gently melancholic black comedy, whose twists and turns build to a sobering climax.
An able touch of sardonic East European humor keeps things smart and light, even if real drama is notable by its absence.
The sensual photography, music and locations are so entrancing ... they help the viewer to overlook the weak storyline, which prefers psychological ambiguity to solid police work.
The touching real-life tale of a Turkish sergeant who saves a small Korean girl becomes long, heart-tugging fiction in Ayla: The Daughter of War, directed by Can Ulkay.
Keeping a step ahead of melodrama is a convincing cast.
The strength of the film is less on the action than the fully embodied characters ...
The choice to shoot in unspectacular black and white and in uninterrupted long takes (par for Hong's course) brands it as mainly for the fan club, whose ranks seem to grow with every new addition.
Engrossing acting rescues an uneven story.
An evocative portrait of a stagnant era.
Anyone who has ever taken an acting class and witnessed the psychodramas brewed there will relate to this bubbling kettle of raw, unleashed emotions stirred up in shifting power grabs.
These timely tales of traumatized kids have a hard time crystallizing into a full-fledged drama.
This light reflection on growing up in a close-knit family of three sisters has a sensibility earmarked for teenagers, and should particularly connect to girls.
Although it seems almost buried in the colorful shenanigans, Pig's political message is there, and this is what the film will be chiefly remembered for.

One can understand young Japanese audiences relating to Kurosawa's casual mixing of retro, tongue-in-cheek sci fi with a bit of coy sociology about how the traditional concepts of family and love are in the process of disappearing in contemporary society.
A cinematically exciting meeting point of the grandiose, the suspenseful and the pathetic.
A relentlessly immersive tour de force.
This study in weathering adversity and adjusting to what life hands you makes some worthy points about human and institutional callousness.

It is saved by its underlying theme of forgiveness and reconciliation between long-estranged family members, for whom the cruel memory of the Japanese invasion and occupation of Singapore during World War 2 is still alive.
To non-Indians, many of the scenes will simply read as high-octane genre fare, but there is a serious target here.
An absorbing moral tale pits one girl against society.
A grimly poignant look at childhood.

The thrills and illusions of love are first celebrated, then painfully exposed, in Jibril, Henrika Kull's thought-provoking tale centered around a dynamic, life-embracing Arab woman living in Germany.
Holland, who had a hit a few years back with the HBO Europe spy series set during the Cold War, Burning Bush, is a mistress of spare, elegant shots that show just enough to advance the story.
[69 Minutes] is one of the works that most strongly brings home the physical and mental hardships of immigration - even if Larsen doesn't show the perilous sea voyage that preceded the first shot.
The message tends to melt into a paint-by-numbers screenplay that pushes too many genre buttons to be thoroughly exciting.
Rather than head the story into straight thriller territory, Al-Daradji and co-screenwriter Isabelle Stead opt for a more philosophical, humanistic turn.
Lively, upbeat and entertaining.
movie_title: Shalom Bollywood: The Untold Story of Indian Cinema (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A unique documentary that is at once atmospheric, gripping and communicative.
This Malayalam comedy with a message becomes heartfelt and endearing thanks to a vivid turn by upcoming actor Dinesh Prabhakar, who is also credited as exec producer and casting director.
Characters come and go quickly, leaving a feeling that there is too much compression of the multi-episode story.
Though far too long at nearly two hours, its stylish look lends it a certain fascination while the story heralds a new filmmaker ready to tackle sensitive issues.
A mild-mannered update on 'The First Wives Club.'
A tough, unsettling film that leaves the audience speechless.
Well-made and amusing if overlong at two hours ...
movie_title: Tremble All You Want (Katte ni furuetero) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's a painful story, but also an illuminating one that is well worth watching.
Tragedy lost in artiness.

Eben Bolter's almost expressionist lighting gives the red-chair interviews a theatrical warmth. The editing, like the acting, is impressively off-handed in the recreated scenes, which flip by like quickly turned pages in a book of memories.
Technically impressive filmmaking, but patience is required.
It's a gripping thriller about a brilliant career assassin, but leaves the audience no more enlightened about the protagonist's motives than a TV newscast.
Both exasperating and endearing in the title role, Rao again shows he is a chameleon actor whose gift for poker-faced comedy revs up the figure of a rigid young civil servant.
Audiences with an interest in Armenia and a working knowledge of the region will find more to love than others in the stirring locations and self-sacrificing characters.
An insightful woman director's POV is a welcome plus, along with an astonishing performance by first-timer Sareh Nour Mousavi in the emotion-packed main role of the motherless Bahar.
Both young actors are naturals horsing around on camera. Chaterjee, a pro who has worked in British films like Brick Lane, cuts a figure as the saucy but resourceful mother.
A cunningly intricate first film from India, Monsoon Shootout combines the best of two worlds - a ferocious Mumbai cops and gangsters drama, and a satisfyingly arty plot that turns in on itself.
Its comedy is too broad and local for most art house audiences to digest.
The format is classic, the scripting smooth and fast-paced and the characters easy to identify with.
An edgy mix of structured narrative and improv.
A passionate film about a woman's ideas.

Remarkably, the film doesn't take sides. This in itself raises it above a purely political discussion in favor of a sweeping criticism of prejudice and inhumanity. Yet it will be remembered as one of the most telling depictions of modern Egypt yet filmed.

A rollicking male-bonding picture about three buddies who open a cricket academy in India's exotic Gujarat, Brothers for Life turns extremely dark and violent in the last half hour, becoming a far more significant film.
Hou Hsiao-Hsien brings a pure, idiosyncratic vision to the martial arts genre.
An anti-war film made with devastating simplicity and painful realism.
Southpaw sticks to tried-and-tested genre rules, yet an edgy cast - led by formidable leading man Jake Gyllenhaal - keeps the story in sharp focus.

The attractive actors are easy to watch, though their silent, enigmatic performances deliberately withhold information from the viewer until the end. Without social interaction of any kind, they remain abstract, symbolic figures.
It's not the stuff of Shakespearean drama, and in fact is barely enough to squeeze a few tears out of audiences into sentimental fare.
The autobiography of Amos Oz, one of Israel's best-known writers, gives structure to Natalie Portman's sensitive if somewhat unfocused directing bow, A Tale of Love and Darkness.
movie_title: A Tale of Love and Darkness (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Wise beyond its years, like the teenage protag Gelsomina, Le Meraviglie (The Wonders) is a wistful but no-tears swan song recounting the disappearance of traditional rural lifestyle in Italy.
Masaan, the Hindi word for crematorium, is part of the new generation of indie films whose clear intent is to set ablaze a hidebound society's constrictions on personal liberty.
The film feels empty and intellectualized at the core, where it should feel powerfully emotional.
Funny and always on-topic without going overboard, it's an engaging film that could broaden Moore's fan base.
It feels like Mehta just wanted to have some fun with an unexplored genre.
At first glance the tall, gangly Patel is an odd choice to play a short, stout mathematician. Yet he captures his essential passion, dignity, and overweening conviction that his formulas are right.
All this material has a hard time coming together in a natural crescendo, and no amount of vibrating violin strings can give it the emotional urgency or focus it badly needs in the closing scenes.
nfortunately, the awkwardly titled Every Thing Will Be Fine seems more like a showcase for expressive camerawork pushing the limits of cinematography than anything else.
[A] universal and enjoyable story told with lively verve and a lot of imagination.
Visually stunning and emotionally engrossing.
The starry cast convinces amid much melodrama.

It's the simplest story imaginable but the director's grasp of child psychology grippingly depicts the boy's anxiety and feeling of being different, while his sensitive cinematic language sets these in the wider context of a coming of age story.
Tale of Tales combines the wildly imaginative world of kings, queens and ogres with the kind of lush production values Italian cinema was once famous for.
movie_title: Tale of Tales (Il racconto dei racconti) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: One waits uneasily for the story to turn dark, but instead the film just runs out of energy in its second half.
Despite the weighty title, this is an extremely light, delicate art film that rarely makes a false move.

Trying to hybridize thick-ear genre material with more artistically ambitious fare, the results are too leaden for the Jason Statham crowd but insufficiently distinctive to find a more rarefied niche.
There are many good things in the swiftly-moving narrative, filmed with a hand-held camera to give a documentary look.
Requires such large amounts of suspended disbelief that one wonders if the film is principally aimed at children.
The modesty of the story, the simple story-telling and honest emotions all come together in a satisfying whole.
Something is missing. Something like credibility.

The toll the disease takes on the life of a brilliant linguistics professor is superbly detailed by Julianne Moore in a career-high performance, driving straight to the terror of the disease and its power to wipe out personal certainties and identity.

The bullets and knives fly thick and fast in a way bound to push the buttons of fans of mindless violence, but there's something missing here that keep these gangsters from blasting their way into great tradition of anti-heroes.

Quiet but pungent and featuring vibrant performances, it offers further evidence that the rebirth of Tunisian cinema is underway, and after its bow in Berlin competition it should find welcoming art film slots.
Not just a chic thriller, but an engrossing study of Italian society and a downward-spiralling economy.
Despite the work of a starry cast, which includes veteran Giovanna Ralli and Cristiana Capotondi, the film has a plodding obviousness that dampens the drama.
Make of it what you will, this off-the-wall film essay entertains hugely while it makes the audience squirm in their seats.

The esoteric world of masterful Turkish filmmaker Nuri Bilge Ceylan proves as vibrant and uneasy as ever in Winter Sleep, a Chekhovian meditation on a marriage that returns to the mood of the director's early films like Climates and Clouds of May.
Timbuktu is a hard film to forget and once again brings Sissako to the center stage of African cinema.
Amazingly, Panahi turns the utterly simple, economical format of a camera inside a car into something relevant to his own artistic state and full of eye-opening insights into Iranian society.
What seems meant as a scorching indictment of American injustice and prejudice, or perhaps the searing character study of a cornered man, just ends up looking wishy-washy and old-fashioned.
An extremely enigmatic work that dangles possible meanings before viewers, who are forced to put their thinking caps on.
The characters are all well-drawn and acting is tough, iconic and credible.
The life of American Poet Laureate Elizabeth Bishop furnishes surprisingly vivid emotional material in Reaching for the Moon.
About Elly confirms director Asghar Farhadi as a major talent in Iranian cinema whose ability to chronicle the middle-class malaise of his society is practically unrivaled.
Black Souls... chooses the classic route of Greek tragedy, which is a natural match for the hard-faced, tight-lipped characters who spiral into general disaster.
Good, strong, understated filmmaking is enlivened by Moretti's characteristic wry blend of drama and humor.
A reflection on destructive sexual fantasies vaunts some wonderfully outrageous and original comedy but an unimpressive final act.
Bjorkman leaves behind the image of a uniquely strong, independent woman whose relaxed modernity was way ahead of its time.
movie_title: Ingrid Bergman in Her Own Words (Jag är Ingrid) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The film's major plus is its exotic atmosphere.
Where Guan excels is in straight dramatization, like the moving, beautifully acted reconciliation in a restaurant between gruff father and impatient son.
Safari is a relatively simple, straightforward and presumably unstaged documentary, but it leaves the audience deeply shaken.
An independent female protag energizes a charming return to the world of Israel's Orthodox Hasidic Jews.
Johnson's screenplay is smooth, fast-paced and persuasive. The protagonists are particularly well-cast.
A uniquely vivid work.
A rousing true love story brings African history to life.
A compelling, true courtroom drama touches on the lingering pain of the Holocaust.
Absorbing if conventional.
Smacks of Nanni Moretti territory but doesn't go far enough in its self-analysis and frankly, isn't very funny or incisive.
A stirring, stinging memorial.
Unpretentious but gently affecting ...
After all the comparisons have been made, this is a magnificent documentary that is going to set the benchmark for history-of-the-universe films in the years to come.
movie_title: Voyage of Time: The IMAX Experience (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Ambience also plays a major role, and Akiko Ashizawa's lighting keeps a cloud of gloom hanging over every shot.
Bilal is a grand-scale, fast-paced animated adaptation that is both empowering and inspiring in its call for social justice and equality.
movie_title: Bilal: A New Breed of Hero (2018)

movie_review_blurb: First-rate Japanese anime is a taste that anyone can acquire in the time it takes to watch a film like this, and it should confirm Shinkai's reputation to genre-lovers around the world, who know his poetry-inspired The Garden of Words.
Using just the right, understated dose of symbolism, the film takes on an especially frightening quality like in a fairy tale whose monster is invisible and invincible.
The film's strong point is the unquestionable beauty of the imagery, filmed over a four-year period in the national parks and animal reserves of Poland, Romania, Norway, Holland and Scotland.
Compared to some of the trashy Japanese slasher fare that passes as entertainment, Museum stands hair on edge without resorting to tons of fake blood or gruesomely realistic offenses to the body.
Irresistibly laugh-out-loud and feel-good.
movie_title: The Brand New Testament (Le tout nouveau testament) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Mehrdad Oskouei's reputation as one of Iran's finest documentary filmmakers grows film by film.
A fine new addition to the library of imaginative children's film fantasy.
The humanism of the finest Iranian cinema shines through the clouds of sadness in Wednesday, May 9.

This first feature by 27-year-old American director Brady Corbet combines a fine Euro cast, grandiose art direction and a thundering score by Scott Walker, but the result is an embarrassing hodgepodge that's very hard to follow.
Like the fighter she plays, Fan Bingbing holds her own against a big all-male cast who are all against her, and shows off her gifts as a comedienne in a surprisingly low-key role.
Too much salt, too little pepper in a silly eco fantasy.
The film can't escape an underlying static quality that extinguishes the flame before it can get burning.

Where journalism leaves off, Fire at Sea (Fuocoammare) begins. It takes a unique documentary filmmaker like Gianfranco Rosi to capture the drama through the periscope of his camera focused on the small Sicilian island of Lampedusa.
A Strange Course of Events... is anything but strange and eventful.
The SFX are convincingly terrifying and involving. The cast is headlined by two of Norway's leading actors, who give the characters unusual depth for a genre film.
A tepid rehash of inter-police wars complicated by obscure behind-the-scenes political machinations.
The dialogue is affectedly scarce, too scarce to sustain and deepen the story psychologically.

Bellocchio stages a gentle, eminently watchable return to some of the key themes that have haunted his 50 years of filmmaking, particularly the scarring left by a dysfunctional family and maternal love gone awry.

Blurring the confines between documentary and fiction, it takes the empathetic viewer on an incredible journey that can be almost as painful to follow vicariously from a theater seat as it must have been on the pilgrims.
All the best things about Asian cinema, rolled into one.

This smoothly told tale is more of a character study than a romance, yet should still draw fans of romance fiction who will particularly appreciate Louis Garrel in the role of the dashing lieutenant Andre Sauvage.
movie_title: From the Land of the Moon (Mal de pierres) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The subject of Francofonia is art as the spoils of war... Making the barest hint about the destruction of historic artworks in Syria at the hands of ISIS, Sokurov gently reminds the viewer why all this is terribly relevant today.

The story could have turned into one huge cliché, and there are genre elements that are numbingly familiar, was it not for the exceptionally scary performance of Nawazuddin Siddiqui in the role of the villainous, demented serial killer Ramanna.
The luminous presence of newcomer Daphne Scoccia holds the film together, though her teen rebel from an underprivileged background looks pretty traditional as far as characters go.
Colorful, corny, unstructured and occasionally magical.
A classic Japanese family drama of gentle persuasion and staggering simplicity from Kore-eda Hirokazu.
movie_title: After the Storm (Umi yori mo mada fukaku) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: An insightful portrait.

The smog that envelopes the teeming metropolis of Tehran, graying out tall buildings and infecting people's lungs, becomes an ominous sign of the times in veteran director Behnam Behzadi's penetrating drama Inversion.
Many scenes seem designed to illustrate platitudes, at the expense of the narrative.

The Wailing is long and involving, permeated by a tense, sickening sense of foreboding, yet finally registers on a slightly lower key than the director's acclaimed genre films The Chaser and The Yellow Sea.

In this fast-moving, densely plotted black dramedy, a faux scandal raised by an ambitious web TV editor comes close to destroying a number of lives, offering a masterful panorama on urban, middle class China.

While the first hour slyly builds up the illusions of a man and his wife using the stranger as a catalyst for their weaknesses, in the second half their guilt and lies come home to roost with a shock. It's hard not to leave the film shaken.
The overall feel is less of a cohesive documentary and more of a slapdash scrapbook of facts, historical information and name-dropping.
A moving, poignant tale about triumph in the face of the unthinkable.
Any sense of predictability is extinguished by these two thoroughly engaging actors. Despite their less-than-saintly behavior, you won't be able to take your eyes off either.
It's become almost trite to criticize him for his recent string of dubious movies, but we'll do it anyway, because he's capable of so much better.
By the time the sun rises and these tormented parallel lives finally intersect, they've all achieved redemption -- as has the movie.
Playing jokes on old people isn't funny.
Mindless, vapid fare.
An edgy drama unwinds with an emotional letdown.
movie_title: L' Ora di Religione (Il Sorriso di Mia Madre) (The Religion Hour) (My Mother's Smile) (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Nearly two hours of an earnest, predictable comedy about a pathetic schlemiel who hopes to redeem himself by acting in the community theater.
Director Christopher Munch deftly raises disturbing questions, but he fumbles badly when groping for answers.
Gabbert expertly delivers a far more powerful message with honesty, humor and palpable respect.
The inspirational tale becomes just another by-the-numbers, cliché-ridden sports film.
A thorough if predictable Behind the Music episode.

Aspires to be a highly stylized exploration of the mind of a serial killer, but it's nothing more than a gory, bloodsoaked snuff film, reveling in its own shock value as women are stabbed, strangled, raped and mutilated.
Just when you thought that the Star Trek phenomenon had truly run its course, along comes J. J. Abrams's stunning prequel to resuscitate the most enduring franchise in sci-fi history.
Soderbergh directs with his trademark pace and panache, but to this he adds an obvious affection for his hapless hillbilly heroes.
Peter and Bob Farrelly better slow down. At the rate they're going, they're bound to run out of material pretty soon.
It coaxes you to laugh and cry, flatters your intelligence, and practically guarantees a cheap night out: at dinner afterward, no one's going to be ordering anything but salad.
Banksy's debut film is poignant without pretentiousness.
This is an optimistic vision for the future of storytelling in Iran -- whatever may come.

Marielle Heller's screen adaptation (which was first a stage adaptation) is suitably warts-and-all, corporeal, and morally complicated -- everything a teen account of their sexual awakening and unravelling should be.
movie_title: The Diary Of A Teenage Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Comparisons aside, this film works because it works as a film - from its artful interweaving and overlapping of sound and image, to its masterful construction of tension, and its naturalistic performances.
Rupert Evans' performance as David is alarming in the shift from unassuming and tender husband and father to demonic neurotic and delusional obsessive.

A shift in focus from a potentially jittery thriller to a humdrum, psychological analysis of a dislocated family becomes the narrative driving force and given the rich backdrop, it appears a great opportunity has been severely missed.

A compelling and propulsive no-holds-barred interpretation, Suffragette does not shy away from accentuating the extreme subversive tactics employed by the bastions of the women's movement in the face of frenzied, brutal opposition.

The introduction of too many ill-conceived sub-plots fails to enhance or execute the essential tenets of the narrative, only serving to detract and distract from the film's overall philosophy, lacking the sharp, subversive edge required for black comedy.

Situating death as the catalyst to action whereby legends, apparitions and spirits mobilize the command to vengeance, Fraser's narrative teems and trounces with relentless bloodshed, slaughter, violence and gore.
Without a high level of mystical intrigue and unnerving eeriness fuelling the story, the plot fails to ignite on a level that would allow for audience investment and identification.
While entering the minds of the perpetrators in The Act of Killing was motivated by action, looking at the legacy of genocide through the eyes of its survivors drives The Look of Silence.

While there is occasional delight of artful satire, fanciful farce, psychological undercurrent and political breadth, it soon becomes evident, as the intricate subplots and subtexts unfold, Ozon has rather overstretched himself again.

The pace of the film is slow, tense and anxious, built upon a motivation for revenge between two antithetical men, who are united through a shared destructive ideology, cementing the absurdity of human ideals.

Disheartening and uncomfortable at times, The Salt of the Earth forces its audience to confront images of a brutal, sometimes forgotten past, deconstructing any notion of an idealized, romantic history.
Paper Souls suffers from a severe identity crisis.
Vanderbilt's attempts at interrogation simply do not get under the skin and fail to penetrate the cynical cycle of corruption and cover-ups, so palpably executed in Spotlight.
Approaching contentious topics with clarity and tact and attempting to find the correct balance between irony and outright offence within a comedic context can often be a tricky affair.
Song of the Sea is a magical feast of visual delights, narrative intrigue and nostalgic revisionism that will appeal to the inner child of all ages.
Executing the hyperactivity of a whirlwind career blighted by controversy and suspicion, The Program pulsates with furious pace, explosive energy and a razor-sharp visual style.

Gillen portrays Carver as a somewhat latter-day Hamlet; an essentially benevolent man who struggles to retain his sanity as he seeks to apprehend his bizarre, fragmented reality through grief and psychological hostility.
Makhmalbaf refrains from idealising a portrait of human anxiety but rather delineates the interchangeability between administering oppression and seeking opportunistic revenge.

Cooper's cinematic scrapbook captures a relentless whirlwind of explosive rock history, in which a non-linear narrative and slick cinematography rollicks furiously through the decades, rooting the audience directly in the band's volcanic timeline.
He may have moved outside to the relative freedom of the streets, however the continuation of the same oppressive narrative persists and he is going to still defy it.
Jupiter Ascending fails to offer its audiences anything other than a one-dimensional and disappointingly regressive visual saga of sci-fi fantasy and 1950s pulp.
While the Scottish landscape has never looked more enticing, sadly, majestic mountains and sweeping seascapes cannot plaster over the uncomfortable cracks in McFarlane's feature debut.

Narratively continuous to the original film but slightly disregarding its two sequels, Jurassic World is a spectacular rush of furious energy, spellbinding awe and alarming terror from beginning to end.

The film's reluctance to overinvest in its religious significance will certainly not satisfy the spiritual nor will it come as a welcome relief to the skeptical, placing the overall audience in a state of limbo.

Despite a formidable and kaleidoscopic performance, there is a sense that the themes of human frailty and the will to heal that inform the film's narrative are beyond Aniston's abilities as a serious dramatic actress.

Kötting's gnomic mish mash of audio-visual experimentation is a deeply evocative sensory exploration that fuses the past and the present, the dramatized and the experimental and the simulated and the real...
The tone of the film is analogically morbid and pessimistic and affecting and sanguine, emphasising the axiomatic transitory condition of mortality.
movie_title: A Pigeon Sat on a Branch Reflecting on Existence (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It is all rather too restraint and temperate an affair, hugely lacking the decadence and opulence of French aristocratic life.
Ultimately, Silver's film does not offer fresh insight into the racial murder of Jordan Davis by Michael Dunn that has not been previously analysed by other media sources.
Danny Collins is, at times, an engaging and downright hilarious comedy drama that will have you laughing through the tears but this is simply owing to the sublime performances from its cast...
Daniel Wolfe is quick to delineate the gendered nature of honour killings and a cultural framework that deifies a son and demonises a daughter.

Ariane Labed is a revelation as Alice, whose nuanced yet emotionally charged performance, not only anchors the core narrative but navigates the philosophical subtexts with both a skittish mischievousness and an intense urgency...
While the film is arguably no better or worse than its literary source, it does shatter the fantasies of sexual desire and sexual pleasure constructed within the novel.
Regardless of its gleaming production and costume design, smooth technical style and frisky musical score, Focus is largely seductive because Smith and Robbie are the seducers.
Symptomatic of the national picture, Girlhood is an unflinching portrait into the seething cauldron of interminable chaos created by the fractured social structures in contemporary Paris.

Goodnight Mommy employs similar psychological tactics found in film noir and the gothic by arousing the same cultural moods of paranoia and mistrust, which have resulted from a disruption to a seemingly, civilized ideal.
Rossi may have aroused an appreciation of Smith's music but he may also have unwittingly refuelled more than a traducing interest in his gnomic demise.

Aware of its own unrivalled mastery within animation filmmaking, Inside Out is a highly self-reflexive, daring and though-provoking feature, which provides a groundbreaking perspective on the narrative evolution within animation itself.

With a big handful of Almodóvar thrown into Cupcake's mixing bowl, and input from the Scissor Sisters' Babydaddy, it will surely find its natural audience.

At three hours, Bangalore Days is a longish film, but the quick pace and neat balance of drama and comedy firmly puts it in the "don't miss" category.
Characters weaken, action withers and the climax turns out to be predictable and far from effective.

Coming from the magic hat of comedian Salim Kumar, it is no wonder that the film is packed with humour. However, he ensures that it is not limited to a slapstick comedy and emphasises the need for an empathetic attitude towards women.

While director Nishikant Kamat's direction needs some help in the first half in particular, there is nothing to fault in writer Jeethu Joseph's original story, which is the stuff cult classics are made of.
As far as stories go, this is simple enough. And in its very simplicity, Bajrangi Bhaijaan tugs at the heartstrings.
This is a rare movie that, in our world of instant endorsements and fleeting moments of fame, has the power of staying with us. Maybe because it feels real.

This docudrama-style thriller hits a raw nerve with a taut script by Vishal Bhardwaj that even-handedly covers the various aspects of the investigation and offers many different versions of the truth.

There are slapdash references to many Hindi films past. If you are a Bollywood junkie, there is much dialogue you have heard before. You can almost finish the lines before the character on screen does.
It left me strangely underwhelmed.
